div.p: THE Grand Informer.
OR The Prerogative of Princes, Priviledge of Parliaments, Propriety of the Subiect, and Power of the Magistrate in point of Civill government fully asserted.

BEING A cleare and iust Vindication of the late proceedings of the Army under the conduct and command of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax: by certain Positions built upon Principles both of Religion and Reason.

div.head: THE Grand Informer.
div.p: IT hath been as the ardent desire, so the great worke and labour of some, both by discourse, preaching and writing, to render odious the late proceedings of the Army, under command of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and by misrepresentations both of their intentions and actions, to undermine the credit and honourable respect which they (through the good hand of God upon them) had purchased in the minds of men, by their former unwearied paines, great hazzards, faithfull deportment, honourable and valliant atchivements; through the blessing whereof the Nation began to returne againe to her rest.

But to the end that no man might take from them, that crowne of honour which God hath set upon their heads, they not having made forfeiture thereof; and to the end 〈◊〉 no ma •• confidence concerning their integrity might be shaken, by the cunning ••••• tions, envious, and malicious ca •••• lado • s of malevolent men: and to the end also that mens thoughts might stand right touching the proper power of the Magistrate- • d the liberty and priviledge of the People, and that men might not (through mistake) cause these to fall foule upon each other, which God hath appointed mutually to •• port each other, therefore I have for the present briefly laid downe some few positions, which I hope will be found serviceable, as to all the fore mentioned ends, so especially in clearing the innocencie of the Army, in their late transactions.
These Positions are as followes.

div.head: The Application.
div.p: Therefore the Army having done so much as they have done towards the breaking of the yoake of tyranny from of the neck of the Nation, and yet finding missery, • lavery, and oppression, comming like an armed man, both upon themselves and the Kingdome, through the operation of much power and malice in conjunction in is faction of men, who have been able to trouble the fountain, and to cause the streames thereof to run muddy, and to cause that hand to wound, which was formerly on purpose to heale: I say this Army having so much interest in the peace of the Nation, and such an opportunity left in their hands of giving check to that insolency, rage, and those unworthy ends of some from whence the grievances of the Kingdome did flow, have done wisely and worthily, and like men of intire love and perfect fidelity to their Country, in standing up to desire, and make termes of justice, equity and security, both for themselves and the Nation.

div.head: The Fifth Position.
div.p: That the ordinary common and standing lawes, and usuall methods of proceedings in a Nation, appointed and concluded in ordinary and common cases, for government and security, may in cases extraordinary be declined, and extraordinary meanes and wa • es made use of in their stead, for the preservation of publicke peace and freedome.

div.head: The Demonstration.
div.p:
If the supreame law, which is the safety of the People, be that which all sorts of men, both of high degree and low, both governours and governed, must principally •• d ultimately mind and observe in all transactions of a publicke nature (a thing which is one of the axeltrees (upon which the wheele of this discourse turnes) then at such times, and in such cases, when a punctuall observation of the letter of the ordinary and •• own lawes of a Land, or the wonted method of proceeding in state affaires, or the temporary commands or decrees of supreame Magistrates, either fall short of, prove insufficient as to provide for and secure the publicke peace thereof; or else in case the principall Officers of a State are abused by mis-information, and are thereby instigated and provoked to issue out orders in gratification of a particular faction in a state, dri
• ing on a particular designe of private interest apparently prejudiciall to the publicke, I say then, and in such extraordinary cases, ordinary and common rules of proceeding 〈◊〉 a state or Kingdome, may be laid aside, and such extraordinary made use of in their •• ead, as hold a neerer and more certaine and immediate connexion, with the common end of all Lawes and governments, viz. common safety, just liberty, and equitable propriety; for this now is a received and undoubted maxime, that when two lawes 〈◊〉 commands come in competition (though both good in their kind) the lesser is all • ales to give place to the greater: The morrall Law of God, as wee call it, and that which wee call ceremoniall, were both good in their kind, and inviolably to be observed by the Jewes: and yet when these two came in competition about one and the 〈◊〉 act; that still carried it which had a more neere and present relation and con
• ex • on with the good and present necessities of men, as best answering the end of those as of all other Lawes: Two or three instances, whereof we have recited by our 〈◊〉 Mat. 17.3, 4, • .7, in justification of an action of his Disciples, censured by 〈◊〉 Ph ••• es, as in transgression of the Lawes of God: the case was this: The Disciples being hungry, and wanting other provisions, gathered cares of Corne on the Sabbath
day, a thing which perhaps according to the 〈◊〉 of the 〈…〉
•••••
sation of God, under which they then were, would be really a transgression of that 〈…〉 of the Sabboth, if that circumstance of present necessity had been wanting, 〈…〉 much as the Sabboth was made by God not to cross, but to accomplish man good, 〈◊〉 to serve his necessityes (as our Saviour argues it in that saying of his; The Sabboth was made for man, and not man for the Sabboth; That therefore that law of the Sabboth was not broken by them as touching the end and scope of it; though perhaps 〈◊〉 touching the letter of it, it might seeme so to be: now those instances of our Saviours to vindicate this act of theirs, a • e of the same nature with it, as evidently appeares by the bare reading of the words, ver. 3, 4, 5. Have you not read what David did when he was an hungred, and they that were with him; how he entered into the House of God, and did eate the shew bread, which was not lawfull for him to eate, neither for them which were with him, but only for the Priests: Or have ye not read in the 〈◊〉 , how that on the Sabboth daies, the Priests in the Temple prophane the Sabboth; and are blameless; and concludes ver. 7. that if they had but understood that saying of God in Hosea 6. 6. I will, or I desire mercy, and not sacrifice, they would not have judged as they did in condemning the guiltless.

Why now then if this be the mind and good pleasure of God concerning man, that rather then he should suffer in his necessary comforts (at such time and in such case, when God hath no need of such sufferings from his creature, for the vindication of any t ••• h of his) he will dispence with his owne commands, so far as the utterall observation of them, seems to cross the generall end and scope of them, which is the benefit of men: Then certainly Gods vicegerents on earth, who are to judge as he judges and to make his mind the rule of their proceedings; have no reason to expes • or to exact from those under them, a more formall and precise observation of their command, then God doth of his: And therefore when the ordinary and knowne L ••• of a Kingdome, or the usuall directions and commands of supreame Magistrates, 〈◊〉 not the true end of lawes and government, which is as oft hath been said, the 〈◊〉 of the people; or doe in the Letter of them really cross the same: if then such other men whom it concernes also to take care and provide for publicke peace, discerning other waies and method of meanes, in prosecution whereof they are upon rational grounds likely to gaine that great and de •• rable end of all instruments and agents 〈◊〉 government, as is before specified: in such cases they not only may, but in Law 〈◊〉 duty to their Country and the prosperity thereof, are bound to follow the 〈…〉 Gods providence, guiding them to digge in that field of means, where the • easure they seeke for, which is the peace of the Nation, is to be found. For when the sup •••• saw, and other subordinate lawes of men come in competition, the ducture of the ••
preame law is still to be followed, according to the rule before recited.

It is a true and safe rule to walke in the observation, as well as in the interpretation of Lawer, viz. That the scope, intent, and spirit of the Law is more the Law the • the letter of it. And therefore because the letter of the Stature lawes of our Land, in many particular cases fals short of that equity and ease, which the law-makers by their should seeke to establish: There is a court of Chancery, or equity provided by way of supply, which is as it were for the correction of the harshness of the letter of ot ••• sixed and •• owne Lawes.

So that if then any number of men furnished with any considerable power, and standing under any visible call to helpe and relieve a Nation in extraordinary ca ••• , wherein neither standing Lawes, nor law-makers, hath made ••••• cient p •• vis • o • for the
••••• tion of common pe • ce, and the fo • mity of honest men shall stee • e a cour •• di •••• ent from common rules in ordinary cases, provided it be in a direct subordination, and proper relation to the end of all la • es, the safety of the people, which is the soveraign and supreame law, I say in su • h cases they are not to be looked upon as transgressors or dis ••• ers of law or lawfull authority, but as upright and faithfull asserters of 〈◊〉 , because they doe not cross but accomplish the true end of it, which is indeed th • power and strength of it.

div.head: The Application.
div.p: Therefore if the Army in the carrying on the great worke for which they were raised; have been necessi •• ted to brea • over the ordinary and common bounds of known lawe, and now at last to refus ••• disband, though commanded thereunto, but yet all in relation to the security of the Nation, and to the end that all men might reap the fruit and benefit of lawes, and to stop the current of A • bitary exorbitances, they may not, they ought not to be reputed destroyers of lawes, nor men disobedient to lawfull authority, but doe worthily deserve the name and renown of the repairers of breaches, and restorers of paths to dwell in; of men that have put their hands to the plow of the Common-wealth, and have not looked back, for though they have exchanged ordinary and common means, as being too low, too weake and too short for those that as extraordinary, & which are more amply & fully proportionated, to the end of their first undertaking, the peace and safety of the Nation: yet they faithfully have, and y •• doe prosecute the same great end, which is the aime and desire of all good Common-wealths men, and for which all just lawes, and lawfull authority were first erected by God amongst men.

div.head: 6. Position.
div.p: That the people of a land, are not so concluded by the votes and determinations of those that have a legislative power, but that they have a liberty of examining and trying the equity and justnest of them, and of dissenting therein upon grounds of non-satisfaction.

div.head: The demonstration.
div.p: Fi • st, Blind obedience is 〈◊〉 wise commendable in, or becomming men: for man is a ••• ionall creature, and while he observes the lawes and principles of his being, he ••• es not but in relation to some end; and the exercise of a mans rationall faculty in 〈◊〉 improvement thereof, consists especially in those two things, (viz.) in the election of his end, and the choise of proper and proportionable meanes that will reach the ends now the common end • at which both Magistrates and people in a land ought to • ime, and to which to proportion their publique actions, is the common good and 〈◊〉 of their nation, and he common people, so far as they act or move towards this end, are not therein to be like beasts which are lead and guided by the hand of their rider without knowledge or consideration of the place to which they goe; but like •••• cting and moving upon rationall grounds, as wrighing and considering whether their actions are of a proper tendency to the publique end they have in their eye, the wisedome of the prudent, saith Solomon, is to understand his way, Prov. 14.8. That is, to know and understand upon grounds of reason, that the course he steers, the m •• ner he makes use of and the actions wherein he ingageth, doe all lead and propend to, and not th ••• t his end.

But impossible it is that the people of a nation should thus act like men in executing the commands of their rulers, unlesse they first examine and try them, and weigh the actions in which they are required to engage, as whether they are not pointed and
postured against or beside the end proposed, or whether they hold a due proportion therewith. And upon examination and tryall the people are to execute, or decline the execution of their commands according as they find them consonant or dis ••••• to the common and publique end.

And truly men may with as much face of reason expect that the common people of a land should cease to be men, and like Nebuchadnezzar, should goe and eate grass with the beast of the field, as to expect that they should be moved, and carried hither on thither to doe this and that by command of their Governours, before they do first sit in judgement in their own thoughts about or concerning the things to be done; as whether they relate to, or rise up against the common interest of the nation, which is the price for which every inhabitant is to run.

Secondly, Either the people of a land are concluded by the votes and determinations of those in authority, as touching what they are to doe for the publique safety, or they are not, if they be concluded, then those in authority are either infallible in their judgements and decrees, as touching their fitness to the end to which they ought to relate, or else that they be not, then the people of a nation may be necessarily ingaged to act towards their own ruine, and to the ruine of their nation, either of which to assert is most absurd.

For that men in authority are subject to erre in their publique administrations, or to miss either the end at which they ought to aime, or else if not, that yet in the choise of sutable meanes, is a thing unto the truth hereof both holy and humane history. Together with the experience of this present age will abundantly witness, and that if the people of a nation were peremptorily concluded and bound up by what the higher powers decree to be done in order to the government of it, and to submit to and act in the accomplishment of such decrees, as oft as they are thereunto required by those powers, should they not, at least be many times ingaged to be active in and accessary to their own ruine, and the desolation of their nation, the which to be, how contrary, it is both to the law and light of nature, and the soveraign and supreame law of Nations, and Kingdomes, is a thing obvious to every mans apprehension.

But if the commonalty be not alwayes absolutely concluded by the orders, decrees and determinations of the higher powers, as is most certaine they are not for the reason before exprest; why then evident it is, that there is alwayes reserved and left unto the people a twofold liberty; 1. A liberty of weighing, trying, examining and judging by common rules of equity and reason, all such orders or decrees as are is •• ed out by the higher powers; as namely, whether the nature and tendancy of them be to promote the common interest of the Kingdome, the adaequate end of all just decrees, or whether some particular mens private interest, that is inconsistant with co ••••• good. And then 2. a liberty of non submission unto such orders or decrees, and a libertie of endeavouring so far as there is opportunity to prevent the evill and mischiefe of them, in case such men upon a serious and judicious debate of the matter in their own thoughts, are able to discover upon sober and rationall grounds, that the • ace 〈◊〉 them is set against the common good of the nation.

But if it be said, that the people are subject to erre in their judgements, and ap • rehensions concerning the proceedings of the higher Powers, as well as they themselves are subject to erre in their proceedings; and then whether is it most meet and reasonable, that the judgement of the people, or the judgement of men in authority should take place?
To this I answer.

First, That things of common equity, and which are of publique concernment for good, doe not lye at any such great distance from the apprehensions of most men, but that they may be felt and handled as it were by them: For who knowes not, that for every man to injoy and securely possess his own right is good? And who knowes not but that every one that would detaine from, or dispose him of it; should therefore be punished? And who knowes not that the eare of the Magistrate should alwayes be open to receive the complaints of, and his hand ready to relieve the oppressed and grieved; and that without any tedious delayes or vexatious attendance; and much more without any reprehention or censure for so doing? And who knowes not, but that those that have taken extraordinary pains, and run extraordinary hazzards in the publique service of the Kingdome, should, receive a thankefull acknowledgement and a considerable recompence and reward from the Kingdome, by the hands of them who are set for the praise of them that doe well. And who knowes not that the cherishing and incouraging of such men, will be an incentive to others for the future in like cases of extremity, to become alike serviceable to the Common-wealth. And that a contra
• y carriage toward such is as the plucking down of the hedge of a nation? And who knowes not but that the provoking of such, who under God, have served a nation it selfe?, who knowes not but that it will be an imprudent, unmanly, and unmercifull act in men, who having swords in their hands, would lay them down for o • hers to take up, whom they know would make no other use of them then to destroy them and other honest men? And who knowes not that all such decrees; orders, & votes of the higher powers, as that contribute any thing to the inconveniencing of an nation in any of the forementioned particulars, or in others like them, have no faire consistancie with the ends of those powers; and therefore as touching such things as are to be dis
• emed by their own light, and which are the subject of every mans thoughts or apprehension, there needs no dispute to arise; or question to be made about truth of judgement concerning them, if any man should deny that the Sun shines when indeed it doth, or that twice two makes foure, where such a negation, worthy a mans consideration, or would it at all weaken the credit and authoritie of his saying, who affirmes the contrary. And doubtless if in matters of common cognizance, and vulger observation, the Magistrate shall doe things contrary to his trust, and the end of his calling, it will be but vaine dallying in men, in case they should go about to cover the same by saying who are fit to be judges of the proceedings of Magistrates, but Magistrates themselves, and why may not those that complaine of them, being ignorant of the mysteries of state, be mistaken in their thoughts concerning them? for if such sayings as these in such cases were to be regarded, and that those that doe oppress shall have the s • le power of determining what is oppression and what not, it will then follow that all the people of a nation must be absolute slaves, if their Governours have a mind to make them so.

2. When the generallity of the people in a nation are of one mind and sence, and lift up their voice together, by way of complaint, concerning the proceedings of their rulers, it is a shrewd signe there is too much truth in such a politique report, for in such cases that saying, Vox populi, Vox Dei, the voice of the people is the voice of God, is not lightly to be passed over.

3. There is not the like temptation lyes upon the people of judging unrighteously concerning the proceedings of Magistrates, as there is upon Magistrates to doe unrighteously in their proceedings, because the complaints of people against those Magigistrates, where there is no cause, may very possibly draw his correcting hand upon
their heads, but is no wayes likely to prove any matter of gaine or advantage to 〈◊〉 , And certainly it is more then an ordinary straine of unworthiness in men, that 〈◊〉 them to lye for nothing But now men in authority have opportunitie in their 〈◊〉 if their hearts will but serve them, to make use of it, to advantage themselves, and to convert that power which is committed to them for publique good, to private int ••••• A sin which in most ages of the world hath been too common among Rulers. N ••
〈◊〉 know that by how much less men are personally concerned in things they attest, by so much the greater probability there is of the truth of their testimony, and therefore when Mag •••• tes shall insist upon their justification, and the generallity of the people in •• t on their compla •• ts, it may well incline an ingenious mind to adhere to the peoples complaint • , as the • ruest report.

If it be further laid, that if this doore of liberty be opened for the common people of a nation, to sit in judgement in their own thoughts upon the proceedings of their governours; is their not withall a flood-gate opened unto faction, rebellion, and sedition to over-flow the land.

To which • answer these three things. 1. That if men in authority demeane themselves so in their places, and in the exercise and execution of their power, that righteousness run down from them like a streame, and that their administrations be such as proclaime love, good will, and faithfullness in them, to their country, as it is very 〈◊〉 to see such Magistrates disquietied in their seats of justice, so they shall not need to feare how na • ed, bare, and ma • fest their proceedings be to all eyes, not how much they are looked into and examin •• (He that doth truth commeth to the light, that his deeds may be made manifest that they are wrought in God, Iohn 3.21.) for in such ••
ses the more they are known. the less they will be mistrusted. And it is not: the ••••
ledge of the well doing of such men who are in authority, that is wont to cause dis •••
tents and sidings in a nation (For if ye be followers of that which is good, who i •
〈◊〉 will harme you, as saith the Apostle, 1 Peter 3.13.) But it is the observation and s •••• of the evill, and unjust proceedings of such men, to the oppression and griefe of the •• breth • en, that gives being unto such commotions.

And therefore secondly I answer, that the shutting of this doo • e of just liberty a • against the people, and keeping them in darkeness, and expecting from them a blind obedience, grounded only upon an implicite saith, is a principall, cause of a g •••
〈◊〉 at least of those evills which many times are as a moth unto a nation, the pro •• th is, tha • it is opportunity that makes a thiefe, and it is as true, that it i • o •••• i ••
〈◊〉 makes an unjust ruler; for doubtless if men did not so • otally, resign themselves and their affaire • (as generally they do) into the hands of their rulers and did not 〈…〉 (as for the most part men have been taught to doe) in what their. Go •••••
〈◊〉 without enquiring into the reasons and grounds of their proceedings, 〈…〉 what relation they have to common good, men in authority would not take 〈◊〉 , confidence and boldnesse unto themselves as many times they do • to 〈…〉 upon the people, and to ride them out of breath. It is because they 〈…〉 themselves like bruit beast that are made to be taken, a • the 〈…〉 that incourageth them to become as a snare unto Mispa •• , and as 〈…〉 as they were, Hos. 5. E. It is the unmanliness, supine 〈…〉 of the people, that tempts those in authority over them to abuse them. Hos. 〈…〉 phraim is oppressed and broken in judgement because • e willingly, walled after 〈◊〉 comma • dement Because Ephraim readily yeelded obedience to what e • es 〈◊〉 dement came from his Rulers; swallowed down all without ch • wi ••
〈…〉
without c ••• ming, therefore his r • lers were •• bold • ed to serve themselves of him, they oppressed, and even brake him to peeces when they sate in judgement.
Therefore manifest it is, that the liberty before as • erted in the right use of it, doth not at all tend to ingender, but to prevent those sad inconveniences laid in the objection.

But thirdly and lastly, I answer that if it were granted that wicked and dissolute men •• y abuse such a liberty which (as the position asserts) belongs unto the people, to such a degree as is mentioned in the objection (as it is possible that their may be a spirit of such wickedness in men, though it's no way probable that such bad fruits should grow on so good a Tree) yet then the objection may be retorted, and so the exception stands more strongly against that absolute unquestionable, and unexaminable power in the Magistrate, which the objection labours to settle upon him by endeavouring to soyle the argument, which doth oppose it; then the objection it selfe doth against the liberty of the People: For if the People may not have liberty to weigh the proceedings of men in greatest authority over them, in the ballance of equity and reason, and to dissent from them therein, in case they be found to light; and all upon this ground, viz, because men under colour and pretence of a rationall dissenting from the Magistrate in his proceedings, may without any just reason or cause at all grow factious, and raise parties in a state against the Magistrate and his just and lawfull administration: then neither is it in anywise meet that any men in authority whatsoever, should have any such unlimmited power put into their hands, as to order and decree what they will, and to doe what they please in managing the affaires of a common-wealth without being accountable unto any: because there is much more danger of their abusing such a power to oppress the People, then there is of the Peoples abusing their honest and just liberty to rebellion and faction: for it cannot be de • yed but that Magistrates are men subject to like infirmities, to like inormities, and to like temptations with other men: Neither can it be denyed upon any colourable pretence, but that they may (de facto) exceed their due bounds: Mow as for the People, they • a •• ot rise up unjustly against, or provoke the Magistrate, Prov. 20.2. but they sinne against their owne soules, or lives, as Solomon speakes, in as much as they runne a desperate hazzard of them thereby; but the Magistrate (upon supposition that he is unaccountable to man) runs no such hazzard of his life by doing unjustly; and therefore be having more opportunity and greater temptations upon him, and having the same principles of frailty as other men have, rendering him obnoxious to corruption, is therefore more likely to miscarry in abusing of his power, then the People are in abusing their liberty. And therefore as I say the objection being retorted, is of far greater force against the power implicitly contended for in the objection, then the objection it selfe is against the liberty of the People. asserted in the Position.

div.head: The Application.
div.p: If the People of a Nation have liberty of trying the conclusions of State, and of disserting therein upon due grounds of non satisfaction; then the Army de ••• ring upon some Votes of Parliament, and suspending the execution of them, are not thereupon forthwith to be censured as men disobedient to Authority; but the reasons and grounds of their so doing are to be taken into consideration, and in case the grounds of their proceedings, and their proceedings themselves, doe comport with the publicke interest of the Kingdome (I nothing doubt but that a few daies experience will give the Nation this assurance into her bosome) then well may that mouth of clamour and evill speaking, that hath been so widely opened against them, be stopt, and every man take shame unto himselfe that hath lifted up a tongue, and that would have lifted up 〈◊〉 against them.
